ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

SALE OF STATE LAND FOR DEVELOPMENT


    1. Mr Arthur Fong asked the Minister for National Development in view of the limited residential and commercial land in Singapore, will he require HDB and URA, when inviting tenders from developers to buy land for development in built up residential estates particularly the HDB heartland, to consider the views of residents who will be affected by the development.

    The Minister of State for National Development (Dr Vivian Balakrishnan) (for the Minister for National Development): Sir, State land sold through tender is developed according to the Master Plan. The Master Plan indicates the intended land use of all parcels of land. In preparing the Master Plan, the URA will, as far as possible, ensure that the adjoining developments are compatible with one another. Extensive public consultation is also carried out before the Master Plan is finalised.

    For major development proposals in HDB estates, the HDB will also brief the Advisors and grassroots organisations of the future developments within the estates. For example, the redevelopment proposals in Clementi Town, which

Column: 1807

include new developments within the Town Centre, are exhibited so that the public can express their views and provide feedback on these proposals.

    As you can see, there are mechanisms in place to inform and consult the public on our plans. However, it is not possible nor practical to consult every single neighbour or stakeholder for each individual project before development. Where we do consult and where competing interests and views are expressed, ultimately, the Government will have to make a decision on the final land use, taking into consideration the larger interests of the community.

    Mr Arthur Fong (West Coast): Sir, the redevelopment of towns undertaken by the HDB is communicated to residents. What about for land that has been tendered out to private developers, which the HDB might know about its use? Should the information not be communicated to the residents who will be affected?

    Dr Vivian Balakrishnan: Mr Speaker, Sir, regardless of whether it is for private or public development, wherever possible, the HDB will inform the Advisors and the grassroots organisations of the impending use of the land.

Column: 1807

MEDISAVE


    2. Mr Arthur Fong asked the Minister for Health if the Government will consider allowing Medisave to pay for the hospitalisation and delivery cost for the fourth child, as there is a growing number of Singaporeans affected by the current ruling, and falling fertility rate, which currently at 1.48, is among the lowest in the world.

    The Minister of State for Health (Dr Balaji Sadasivan) (for the Minister for Health): Mr Speaker, Sir, I wish to clarify that Medisave is primarily intended for inpatient hospitalisation expenses. For maternity purposes, Medisave may be used for the delivery of a woman's first

Column: 1808

three children. This is in line with the national population policy of encouraging couples to have three or more children only if they can afford it. Couples who decide to have a fourth child or more must rely on their own finances rather than on Medisave to pay for the delivery expenses.

JUNIOR COLLEGE/UPPER SECONDARY EDUCATION


    Order read for resumption of Debate on Question [25th November, 2002].

    "That this House, having noted the Report of the Junior College (JC)/Upper Secondary Education Review Committee 2002, contained in Paper Cmd. 8 of 2002, (1) supports the new JC curriculum which will better develop thinking, communication and other process skills and engage students in greater breadth of learning; and (2) endorses greater diversity and opening of new pathways in JC/Upper Secondary education to cater to the different strengths and interests of students.". - [Minister for Education].

    Question again proposed.

    Mdm Ho Geok Choo (West Coast): Mr Speaker Sir, my parliamentary colleagues in the last two days have debated on the merits and demerits of our existing education system as well as the recommendations in the proposed new model.

    Among some of the pertinent points brought up in the debate were concerns with implementation of the recommendations, in particular, how can we ensure that teachers are able to deliver effectively. Other points pertain to the further stress that will be loaded on teachers, parents and students because of the introduction of new subjects as well as the danger of creating an elitist society.

    Having heard through the debate, I am reminded of a Sunday school song that I used to sing and used to feel very troubled when singing it. The lyrics of the song go this way:

    Look all over the world,

    No one likes me,

    Look all over the world,

    No one exactly like me,

    Some people are short and

    Some people are tall,

    But God loves them all.

Column: 1809



    I used to feel very troubled singing these lyrics until one day, I ventured to ask my mother why is it that "no one likes me", and that was when my mother gave me a lesson on the reality of the world that we are living in.

    She told me to put out my 10 fingers and to note that the 10 fingers are of different lengths and they also bear different fingerprints. However, each finger is unique in itself and they are all precious to our Creator. So, it was about being different and not about being liked.

    Going by this illustration, at home, our siblings can be very different from one another, yet we are all loved by our parents. Extend that to the nation state; the citizens are all different individuals, yet they are all loved by the Government.

    This reminds me of what NMP Dr Jennifer Lee has mentioned about the 400,000 potential workers at the bottom rung of the ladder. In fact, I would say that 75-80% of the student cohort will not benefit from the revised recommendations for the Upper Secondary Schools and the JCs.

    Anecdotally, this is similar to putting nail polish on the two middle fingernails. When we hide away the other eight fingers, the fingers with nail polish look very pretty. However, when you put up the other eight fingers, the two middle fingers with nail polish that happen to be the longer ones will stick out like sore fingers amongst the other eight fingers with no nail polish. This pair of hands will not look as pretty as another pair of hands with nail polish on all the finger nails. So, the way to close the gap between the top 20-25% and the other 75% is really to level up the lower cohort.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, this is where Dr Jennifer Lee's and the other MPs' point about the need to take care of the other 75% or so of the student cohort begs attention, lest we inadvertently cultivate students who feel that "no one likes me".

    Granted the fact that resources are limited and that it is only natural that

Column: 1810

resources are allocated to investments that give the best payoff, no one begrudges that we ought to concentrate our resources on the top 20- 25% of our student cohort. This is one way that we can ensure that our creme-de-la-creme are nurtured to continue to lead our nation and economy into the future. Nonetheless, it is necessary that there must be some leftovers for the other 75% or so.

    Granted that the schools cannot afford to give equal resources to the other 75% and the fact that going forward, our economy depends also on the input of the other 75%, how can MOE ensure that this 75% will be given the opportunity for that life long learning?

    As pointed out by my parliamentary colleague, Assoc. Prof. Koo Tsai Kee, education is a life long journey. Preparing our students for the new society requires a long-term plan where we will need to continually educate knowledge workers. This is because knowledge workers, unlike the traditional workers, no longer work with their hands, and knowledge gets obsolete very rapidly because it is made irrelevant by advanced improvement in science and technology.

    Therefore, what the Ministry is doing in terms of providing the foundation and fundamental training for the general cohort of our students is correct. However, I would like to urge that the Ministry thinks beyond the schools to ensure that the majority of the product of its system is given an opportunity to level itself up when it is in the real working world. In this way, this lower cohort can continue to contribute to the economy, although they may not be at the helm of leadership.

    This is where I would like to compliment the Sub-Committee of the Economic Review Committee on Enhancing Human Capital. The Sub-Committee has come up with two very pertinent recommendations that I feel the MOE should make a point to support, although I reckon that it is not in the charter of the MOE to bother itself with adult education.

    Nonetheless, the directions and long-term plan of the MOE to churn out

Column: 1811

knowledge workers of the economy cannot be formulated in an ivory tower. The determinants of MOE's policy are very much grounded in the working world.

    The two recommendations of the Sub-Committee of the ERC on Enhancing Human Capital make important reference to educating and nurturing our students for the new society. We are aware that the new society will be a society populated by knowledge workers.

    Knowledge is unlike traditional skills, which change very slowly. To give an example, a museum near Barcelona in Spain contains a vast number of hand tools used by skilled craftsmen of the late Roman Empire, which any craftsman of today would recognise immediately because they are very similar to the tools that are still in use today.

    For purpose of skill training, it is therefore reasonable to assume that whatever that has been learned when you are 17 or 18 years of age would last for a lifetime.

    On the other hand, knowledge becomes rapidly obsolete and knowledge workers have to regularly come back to school. Continuing education of already educated adults will become a big growth area in the future. The information revolution which already has an enormous impact on education and on traditional schools and universities will probably have an even greater effect on the continuing education of knowledge workers.

    Hence, the recommendation on stimulating creativity and innovation by the ERC Sub-Committee. I quote:

    'Our prime engines of growth will need to be fuelled by capabilities that are indigenous, knowledge-based and services-oriented with a greater emphasis on value creation, innovation and international orientation. We need our organisations to be places that consciously and intentionally enable workers to be at their best and, at the same time, build and expand their capabilities to become more productive, more resilient, able to tap their creativity and initiative, and bring forth new innovation.'

    How can our schools partner the corporate world for this bigger game plan?

Column: 1812

Here, I would like to recommend that our schools partner the corporate world to develop a virtual creativity and innovation centre. The whole idea is to encourage students to upload their creative ideas and the best ideas could then be rewarded publicly.

    Support perhaps could be given to the contributors of these ideas through adoption by an interested company, for example. Such initiative can go a long way to benefit the other 75% of our student cohort. To nurture a bigger cohort of students for more creative and innovative contribution, the environment and infrastructure must be all-encompassing.

    The second recommendation of the ERC Sub-Committee on Enhancing Human Capital is on transforming the education institutes into suppliers of knowledge workers. It was stated in the recommendation that "we need to re-position schools and universities, so that in addition to teaching and educating, they serve as creators of knowledge, engines of innovation and cradles of enterprise".

    Perhaps, schools can explore the possibility of tying up with the corporate world to run a KBE-Readiness Enhancement Project, which the objective would be to ensure that education institutes supply operational knowledge workers to the corporate world.

    In such a project, representatives of education institutes and representatives of the corporate world could meet, to assess which key knowledge, skills and traits the business organisations most urgently require of their employees but feel are not yet properly encouraged/developed by the education sector.

    Both parties can then identify how the corporate world can most efficiently help the education sector in developing these knowledge, skills and traits, and which third party may help with this project. Such help can actually be done through lectures, provision of case studies and other materials, internships, exchanges and interviews.

Column: 1813



    Sir, the suggestions outlined so far attempt to close a gap between the top 25% and the other 75% of the student cohort, which if left unattended, will only widen the divide. All that MOE needs to do to make this happen is to take a more flexible approach in extending itself beyond the schools and link up with the resources in the corporate world.

    Notwithstanding the good and timely work put in by the Committee, I would like to highlight four other issues for review by MOE.

    The first area of concern which MPs have talked about pertains to having enough supply of teachers. My parliamentary colleague, Mr Chew Heng Ching, has suggested that we should look to taking in more foreign teachers. I would propose that we also should look to the pool of retrenched executives who would be able to take on a second career as teachers because their commercial and real life experiences will put them in good stead as non-academic character development programme specialists.

    The Minister for Education, RAdm Teo Chee Hean, has stated in his speech at the Ministry of Education Investiture of the 2001 National Day Awards in January 2002 that one of the key challenges for the Ministry of Education in the years ahead is to continue to build high quality teachers. He had acknowledged that good teachers are the foundation of a good education system. The challenge, he said, was to ensure that we maintain a high standard of teaching profession even as the profile of the teaching force changes.

    Sir, 3,500 of our experienced teachers will be retiring over the next five years. This lot needs to be replaced. With the revised syllabus, we know that there is an additional load on existing teachers and we need to beef up the pool. Besides, MOE also has to recruit more teachers in preparation for the larger student enrolment at the secondary and junior college levels over the next few years. Student enrolment at this level is projected to increase by 25,000 from 220,000 today to 245,000 in year 2006.

Column: 1814



    The Ministry was expected to recruit 3,000 new teachers for the recruitment cycle which started in August last year to July this year. This recruitment was supposed to replace those who are retiring and also to set up recruitment in advance for secondary school and junior college teachers.

    I wonder to what extent the Ministry has met its target. We are aware that, apart from the traditional source of fresh graduates joining the teaching service, the Ministry has also been recruiting those with some working experience as teachers. This is very encouraging and opens a window of opportunity and hope for the many retrenched executives today.

    I would urge that the Ministry consider a conversion programme that will put the professionals, executives and managers who have been retrenched through a non-academic teaching diploma course within this 3-year window before 2006. This group of retrenched executives constitutes a fairly high percentage of the retrenched employees of 100,000 in Singapore today. They can be converted to be economically active and gainfully employed again.

    We may lament that the issue really is that we can have such a scheme but there would be no takers. Well, I reckon that in this aspect, we need to champion for the fruition of such a scheme and even launch campaigns to bring about awareness of a second career in teaching.

    In this, perhaps the MOE could partner the National Job Task Force and other agencies such as SPEC, to identify suitable candidates, design the conversion programme for character development and deliver the programme. Such effort and new opportunities in the education industry will give a boost to these retrenched executives who will be able to find hope in a second career in this industry.

    The second area of concern has to do with the broader range of subjects that students are now faced with and would

Column: 1815

have to make a choice. Independent counsellors may be needed because of the much wider choices to be made by students in the Integrated Programme.

    Our students have had little experience of free and wide choice. So far, they have been channelled through the whole education system almost totally on the basis of their various scores. They and their parents are not ready for freedom of choice to this extent. These independent counsellors could be trained up from the ranks and file of the retrenched professionals, executives and managers.

    In the third area of review, I would advocate that we integrate project work into the real life working environment. As project work gives an opportunity for nurturing EQ and character development, as well as leadership, we ought to think in terms of internship during school vacation for students in the working world. Therefore, arrangement should be made to encourage employers, as good corporate citizens, to help nurture the future manpower of Singapore by being more forthcoming in their internship programme.

    However, experience has shown that if there is no proper monitoring of this type of programme, very often these interns end up as mere hands and legs in organisations. This is really a waste because it would not provide these students with the necessary learning that they are looking for.

    In this instance, it would be good for MOE to think in terms of how they can work out a suitable programme with employers to enhance some of these internship programmes for project work.

    The fourth issue I would like to raise is that the Review Committee's proposal is not clear as to what percentage of the learning will be on nurturing the student in the EQ and character development aspects.

    In the area of EQ, besides the innate characteristic of an individual, I believe a

Column: 1816

certain amount of nurturing and exposure can actually create awareness in an individual to realise and understand the importance of developing strengths in this area.

    This proposal has recommended that one way to do it is to allow the nurturing of these characteristics to reside in the non-academic area. It would appear to me that a paradoxical situation could arise for a young teenager in the JC because he would be torn between focusing his energy in the academic pursuits rather than striking a balance simply because the non-academic pursuits may not be given equal weightage in terms of measurement.

    This is fine provided that there is a campaign to create understanding and awareness amongst our teachers, parents and students, that though not as measurable as the academic pursuits, the non-academic pursuits will be recorded as track record and experience.

    Due recognition for such pursuits should include appropriate and meaningful proportionate weightage in the admission into university programmes as well as for appointments in their careers. It is necessary to establish a quantitative measure of non-academic or co-curricular work in order to incentivise pursuit of such activities.

    In the US, the top universities like Yale, Harvard and the other Ivy League universities place great emphasis on students' co-curricular activities in their admission criteria. Of course, the applicant has to fulfil the basic requirements but it is common knowledge that the student's non-academic activities have important weightage. In our case, the university admission criterion states a bonus 5% on CCA, which for all the big bang on promoting non-academic pursuits as in the recommendations, would be insignificantly effective.

    Together with project work which encompasses a big chunk of EQ quality and integrating skills, would MOE consider increasing this aspect of learning and

Column: 1817

development, ie, CCA and project work to 15% of the university admission criterion? This is approximately equivalent to the credits earned in one subject. Since much time is spent on such pursuits, we ought to give some credit here and not because many Singaporean students adopt the attitude of "if you give me points then I'll do it".

    Yet we know that in truth, there may be little sport done by these students for pure enjoyment. CCA is not imparting mental strength in many of our students. It does impart a scoring mentality. This happens because we have yet to be able to deliver a system, which would motivate students to pursue purely for the love of it.

    I am not advocating for a materialistic approach but being practical about things, in my opinion, the idealistic philosophy of "I do it for the love of it" has got to be cultivated. It takes time to do that, and in the interest of time, let us begin by buying in as many as possible, with an approach that can win big scores among Singaporeans. Once we have achieved a culture for the non-academic pursuits, we can then throw away measurement.

    In fact, co-curricular activities of a person are given high weightings by multinationals corporations such as Shell, Exxon-Mobil and Mars Chocolates. They have a value-add contribution in determining the holistic individual.

    In conclusion, I ask what should any system of education set out to achieve?

    According to a recent study conducted by Towers Perrin, the attributes most sought after today include creativity, the ability to learn, versatility, awareness of the business environment and the ability to think beyond functional and cultural boundaries. These attributes encompass a combination of knowledge, skills and mindsets or attitude. In a sense this model, attitude, skills and knowledge, the ASK model, gives us something to start with but we need to think carefully about how we go about to achieve this.

    The underlying philosophy of any competence-based initiative is based on

Column: 1818

the perceived need to help individuals respond to an environment, which is becoming increasingly diverse and unpredictable. The revised JC and upper secondary course syllabus should incorporate a competence approach to development and learning to learn for all and not just the top 25%.

    What we should be looking at is a broader definition of learning - one that is process orientated, integrated, holistic and ongoing for all. And that also takes into account the wider environment, as well as the learner's personality traits. I believe that the recommendations of the Review Committee would ultimately drive towards these objectives.

    I urge the Ministry or the Committee to be responsive to suggestions for improvements made and to initiate a whole new discussion on the implementation follow up.

    On this note, I would like to support the motion.

    Ms Braema Mathiaparanam (Nominated Member): Thank you, Speaker, Sir, for letting me join in the debate. I rise in support of the motion and also to raise a few concerns.

    I found the Education Review Committee's report on the Upper Secondary/Junior College curriculum well-placed in wanting to give students a breadth in knowledge as well as depth in subjects that they hold dear.

    I was particularly excited by the subject 'Knowledge and Inquiry', seeing it as an opportunity to introduce modules, such as certain aspects of university 101 courses, such as anthropology, sociology, cultural studies, management skills, or perhaps best practices, and mass communication skills.

    I am keen on this widening of the curriculum as long as long as it holds true to what I see as a key operational phrase in the report - giving students the "space to pursue". I think it is pivotal that we give them the space and the time to learn, to

Column: 1819

redefine, to review, and the whole process repeats itself again. That is part of the initiative to which I think individuals can pick up those skills to become confident in coming up with new ideas. On a larger scale, I see this initiative as something that is very important to our society because it is giving a clear signal that perhaps from maybe 2006, or from now on, we are placing a larger emphasis on the value of learning, the process of learning, rather than just the facts. So I commend and congratulate the Committee for coming up with such a proposal. It is going to take some time for people to shift their gears into understanding what it all means at the ground level.

    Coming now to the concerns, primarily, I would have been most comforted if the report had also engaged itself on the ranking scheme, the university admission criteria and the appraisal scheme for teachers. These have to be in tandem and aligned with the outcomes of this new review where the curriculum is concerned. If we are expecting our students to perform according to these indicators, whatever the outcomes be, then likewise we should be following that through with an appraisal scheme, whether it is appraised in schools, whether it means admitting students into university or appraising teachers in tandem.

    Let me just go back to an old issue that has come up in Parliament many, many times, in the media and, I am sure, in many feedback sessions - the great ranking scheme. It has always been based on pure academics, whether it is the value-added side, or whether it is just the schools or JCs, they are ranked according to the academic achievements of the students. Perhaps this has led to, at the ground level, a lot of us sacrificing what is the learning process and going just for the score.

    Let me just give an example. As a former teacher trying to persuade students or coming to that kind of conflict, whether I should persuade a student to

Column: 1820

drop Literature because the grades are not there, or whether I should let the student continue, it is a tough scheme to be up against the system that does not encourage the breadth that we are right now seeking when we are interested only in the scores. So I am heartened by this recommendation. But I also wish the ranking scheme can be reviewed as part of that recommendation.

    What I would like to see, and this has been suggested before, is the schools and junior colleges listed in alphabetical order with perhaps five stars for particular strengths, be they in Sciences, Moral Education or whatever, and three stars for internship programmes. Such a resource library of information for parents to choose and for students to choose what they would like to pursue will be a clear signal that we are giving to society as to what we are putting emphasis on.

    Another side effect of the ranking scheme, at present, is that a lot of polytechnic students end up having remedial classes in additional Mathematics because they have been encouraged to drop it, or it was not offered. So the breadth is important if we want things to happen according to this Review Committee's proposals. And ranking, in my opinion, is a stumbling block and can also subvert what the Ministry is trying to do. So it becomes quite ironical.

    Next, university admission criteria. Changes are already happening and it is heartening. However, like Mdm Ho Geok Choo, I too wonder whether the project work could have a higher weightage, and the 'A' levels themselves, instead of 75%, should come down a bit lower. The interviews at universities should play an important role so that we can assess whether the student is capable of whatever the outcome that we are trying to measure the student for.

    Next, teachers' appraisals. It is common knowledge that teachers are appraised on the kind of results that they bring back where their students are concerned. It is quite a major criterion, talking to teachers and principals. They do tell you that it

Column: 1821

plays a part and, in some cases, a big part. Appraisal of teachers is then linked to performance bonuses and teachers themselves are drawn into this scheme. If we do not change the appraisal scheme, making it perhaps even an open appraisal scheme whereby teachers and principals negotiate what they mean by teaching a student to be creative, what they mean by teaching a student to be critical, these are intangibles in a lot of ways, how are we going to measure that and give due credit to teachers so that they do not get demoralised for the efforts that they put in but can continue and buy in into what this recommendation is all about?

    In conclusion, for this aspect of what I am talking about, I feel that I would have been most comforted if there is an assurance that these three areas are going to be in sync, in tandem or aligned with what this report sets out to do.

    Like the others, Dr Amy Khor, Mr Iswaran and Dr Jennifer Lee, I too feel that, while tackling the top, I have got no quarrels with making the system better for the top 25%. I feel that it is equally important to handle the lower primary. I wish that, in the same nine months, this same Committee, or another, could look into reviewing the curriculum, etc, for pupils from Primary 1 to Primary 3. They are the years that really give the child the fundamentals in language skills and in Arithmetic. There are good programmes like LSP and ENABLE. But still, where language skills are concerned, for the demands that are coming up, can we equip our children well enough? So this has to be in tandem too, that we try and fix the lower primary classes as well as the upper end. So I am hoping that that too is on the cards and will surface perhaps quite soon.

    I heard the Minister of State, Dr Ng Eng Hen, and also Minister Teo Chee Hean, on how we have come very far and how we have helped our students to come along. 90% is a good, big average that we have looked after, as what was said, and that a lot of our students now are well equipped to converse in English. This is laudable. I do feel that while it is a good place to

Column: 1822

arrive at when we are in a global world with demands that are becoming greater, we also have to relook at the quality and think about, besides the numbers appearing at 'O' levels and the numbers who are passing through the language courses, the quality of our students. One trend that I personally find disturbing is the number of students who are now ending in the Normal (Academic) stream, not to say that that is a wrong stream. But when we first started with small numbers, I think, today, it is three out of every eight students. And it begs the question that, while we review and do better for the top, offering choices, etc, should we not go further back and try and see what are the trends where quality is concerned? So I am hoping that the review will cover that because, like what was said before, fixing the top is well and good and needs to be done. But the group that is feeding the top too needs to be given better vitamins, etc.

    On this whole issue on the importance of the mother tongue, again, back at JC curriculum level, a lot of our students have become, through 10 years of education, quite well emplaced in their proficiency where mother tongue is concerned. May I suggest that perhaps it is a better idea that we offer a second language, with not the high rigours of a mother tongue at the JC level, that makes them become a global citizen, whether it be something for the region, or something across, and that should give them more language-based skills as well as not to overload them with the mother tongue emphasis. Likewise, the university admission criteria will have to be readjusted.

    Next, the Centralised Institutes. There are 1,063 students who attend the Centralised Institutes. They have a good record of being able to send quite a number of their students to university. My fear here is, under the present 2006 curriculum that is supposed to come, can our students from these Centralised Institutes cope with such high demands? It might be a better idea to take the lower end of the junior college intake, perhaps the 19 pointers and the 20 pointers, fill them with the students from the Centralised Institutes and put them under a college

Column: 1823

programme whereby these efforts are intensified, and they have a better chance of surviving the 'A' levels which we all know is going to get a bit more stressful, and make it to university. Because, by 2006, in my opinion, it can be quite out of sync for them.

    I have a few concerns where implementation is concerned. One of them is the revised curriculum that is to be written. I have some questions. Who would be the planners? What is their expertise? What are their specialist areas? And what kind of training? On the training of teachers, much has been said - Dr Amy Khor has spoken on it and I am echoing that - quite a number of the teacher trainees, who now go through the National Institute of Education, are students who have come through this programme of being quite examination-smart. How are we going to retrain them within the next four years such that we can open up their minds to start thinking more creatively and critically? Could we have some assurance on both the numbers as well as the quality where teacher training is concerned?

    On this issue of the teachers and students, those who are already in the classrooms right now, how are they going to be trained where the training hours are concerned, because we have just got our first group of 'A' level students who are sitting for their 'A' level examination under the revised syllabus? And the teachers have just adjusted to the revised syllabus. I am concerned about who is monitoring this and how will teachers cope with trying to vacillate between two systems, the revised syllabus for the 'A' levels at present as well as the 2006 curriculum that is coming. I would like to hear some kind of a plan or programme in this aspect.

    It is wonderful to have specialised tools to cater to students who want to excel in sports, the arts, etc. But I also wonder, if by this proposal, we are very keen in opening the window and letting students come up with a path that suits them best, why are we not opening the sports school

Column: 1824

to students from the Normal (Academic) stream or the Normal (Technical) stream? Such students will learn much from the discipline of sports to excel also in the academic curriculum with much help from such a school. So it is a little bit beyond me to understand. On one hand, in summary, there is this proposal, a very good exciting one, and yet there are these few things around this proposal that can run the risk of subverting these good intentions.

    Lastly, such a proposal, to be successful - and I personally hope that it will succeed - cannot act in isolation. Society too needs to embrace this proposal, understand what it means for them as individuals - parents, students or teachers - and, with that understanding, force themselves not to be over-eager, not to be so kiasu, as we normally call it, and to give this a chance to breathe.

    With that, I would say that sometimes our obsession with saving face and not wanting to make mistakes, as a cultural norm too, can thwart the progress of such a proposal.

    Mr Arthur Fong (West Coast): Sir, this motion to debate on the White Paper on education in the name of the Minister for Education, RAdm Teo Chee Hean, has caused two different reactions. On one level, that includes most, if not all of us in this House, the stated intentions of the recommendations of the education White Paper are so positively constructed that no one can find fault with. On the other level, some Singaporeans and some of our foreign friends overseas are befuddled with the White Paper. They wonder is it that when our students keep coming out tops at international mathematics and science tests, we are still not satisfied and have to try and change it.

    Sir, I initially had some thoughts along these lines too. I had the benefit of a local education in my formative years and a good overseas tertiary education. When I returned from the US in 1988, I compared and found our local curriculum too stacked up in terms of knowledge acquisition. My colleagues, who were

Column: 1825

local graduates, were extremely competent in the technical aspects of their work and found it interesting when I shared with them the US system where undergraduates must take courses other than classes that are required to satisfy the major that they are taking. Such classes include Holistic Medicine, Speech, Communication and Rhetoric. I was also required to take courses for both an Arts and Science cluster as a Business undergraduate. Without the completion of such university requirements of the clusters, a Business undergraduate may not even get a degree, if the Business classes are completed. The Arts cluster may include subjects like Social Psychology, German Language, Russian Literature, or Geography. Examples of Science clusters include Physics of Light, Astronomy or Fluid Dynamics. This gives students a broader knowledge base and, certainly, some competence in participating in a discourse that is outside their major field of study.

    I had a nagging thought that something needed fixing then, and again thought to myself, our system had met Singapore's national needs for the longest time. So, if it ain't broke, don't fix it or, rather, if it isn't broken, leave it, to emphasise support of RAdm Teo's point that we do have a good standard of English. Also, it was a system that let me stay well above others at a good university in the United States.

    However, then to now, a lot of water had gone under the bridge, to borrow the often-used phrase, "the world has changed". We are indeed in a very different world. Education reform has now become a global trend and is now discussed and has taken centre-stage at many international conferences. Part of the reason for this is the rapid and drastic socio-economic change that is taking place on a global scale. In an era of increased economic competition, it is critical to have a trained and qualified workforce to support, sustain and advance the scientific, technological and economic capabilities of our nation.

    Education reform, as an integral part of a nation's strategic policy, is not something new. The US and the UK have

Column: 1826

promoted improving the quality of education as a means to strengthen international competitiveness since the 1980s. France has integrated educational reform into its policies for the development of the country. China has been using the slogan "Invigorating China through Science and Education". In Japan, two years ago the government has pledged to make educational reform the foundation of all social systems in this century.

    If these countries, which are richer and better endowed in terms of natural resources than us, are giving such a high priority to educational reforms, we too should look at how else we can build upon and improve our system. We cannot stand still. In resource-limited Singapore, we not only cannot afford to stand still, but we need to run doubly fast. I mentioned in one of my speeches during the Budget debate earlier this year that Singapore is like an airplane navigating in very turbulent and difficult airspace. I said that we needed to snap on new engines that will take us through. To do that, we need to look at our education system so that we have the innovative ability to conceptualise to make the tools that will help us build that kind of engine to take us through for years to come.

    In the US, the importance of education and educational reforms enjoys very high level support. In fact, almost every US President in the last 20 years had put their mark on improving education through legislation. We are no different in Singapore. In 1997, the idea of "Thinking Schools, Learning Nation" was introduced. In this regard, we have appended much of our resources to the PRIME initiative. From the completed PRIME schools that I have visited, I must say, even at this middle stage of the programme, it is a great success. Similarly, a lot of effort and resources had been put into getting honest and useful feedback, practical suggestions and to lay down these suggestions and recommendations in the form of the White Paper on education. This will certainly be one of the most important blueprints in the remaking of Singapore.

Column: 1827



    Sir, we all know that having a good education is an important factor, not the only, but certainly a strong contributor towards economic success in life. This is especially true in a meritocratic and academic-driven Singapore. If you have good academic results, you are almost certain of a good employment which, in turn, would provide a good and comfortable life. Thus, having a good employment is a motivating factor for almost every Singaporean in their academic pursuit.

    And in the area of employment, the civil service sends the signal on what is important. In most of the senior positions in our civil service, the minimum entry requirement is at least an Honours (Second Upper). For a student in Singapore, studying hard and aspiring to be amply compensated, his or her work is cut out for him or her, and the route to be taken clearly marked out. They will be singled-minded and study to sit for the examination subjects that will count towards entering the university, never mind that the intent of the White Paper on education calls for a thinking person.

    Sir, in many fields, compensation does drive behaviour. Am I going to spend much time in other co-curricular activities, such as sports or music? Maybe. And only if I have some spare time left after studying the rest.

    Sir, one of the most important determinants that drives students' performance must be university admission. Since the White Paper leaves it to the university/campus to decide on the weighting to be given to co-curricular activities and, at the same time, calls for a downgrading to a 15% SAT, the university/campuses must review their admission criteria too. It would appear that when the recommendations of the White Paper come into play, the admission criteria would be outdated. University admission criteria will have to be redrawn, in line with the proposed changes in the White Paper. Perhaps, there will be another debate then.

Column: 1828



    The recommendation to allow for private schools is a step in the right direction. In the area of knowledge acquisition and the quest for wisdom, no one can claim to have the right of monopolistic hold on it, not the least the Government. It does not do any good to have only one system of education in a country. The existence of private schools would spur greater performance all round. In the US, on a standardised achievement test, ie, the National Assessment of Educational Progress, private school students generally perform higher than their public school counterparts. We already have a high-quality public school system. Certainly, the private schools will also add to setting new benchmarks that we may at some stage consider for yet another White Paper. I would urge then for the Ministry to govern private schools with a light hand and to let the market find its own level in terms of operations, pricing and curriculum. The private schools will then play a value-added role in promoting Singapore as an education hub.

    The White Paper calls for a reduction in the teaching hours for the students to be reduced by 10%, but with an increase in the intensity of the curriculum of 25%. I understand that the teaching staff in the schools that applied for IP is ready to take on the prescribed load. This is not surprising, considering those schools such as the Raffles cluster and ACS(I) had been doing their IP-similar programmes for some years. My fear is for the readiness of the teachers - whom some of my parliamentary colleagues have talked about over the last two days - whether those who are expected to teach the increased intensity subjects as recommended in the White Paper, although at a reduced 1,300-1,700 hours, are prepared.

    Sir, I understand that, presently, a secondary school teacher spends more than 50 hours on average per week on teaching and related activities. In a year, they spend close to 500 hours on non-teaching related activities, such as Sports Day or Speech Day. I wonder if we had thought about over-stretching our teachers a little bit too much. The teachers are an important resource; in fact, very

Column: 1829

important in achieving the goals set out in the White Paper.

    Sir, education is a key to having a competitive and highly qualified workforce. One thing is certain: as sure as there are jobs that have vanished forever, it is also correct to say that there are jobs that have not been configured yet. It is vital, then, to prepare our nation and our people with a wide exposure through education, so that the fit into tomorrow's job evolution is possible. I think this is very important, where we can add to the talent pool that is culturally connected, especially for our leaders-to-be.

    As a Singaporean, I urge all to support this initiative to ensure that we stay ahead of the curve, in order that we may survive in a fast-changing and uncertain world. As a parent, I urge all to understand the importance of these changes in order that our children may have an opportunity to enjoy a more diverse and broader education, and for our country's survival.

    Sir, I support the motion.
1.25 pm

    Assoc. Prof. Ngiam Tee Liang (Nominated Member): Thank you, Mr Speaker, Sir, for allowing me to join in this debate. At the outset, let me declare that, as a university educator, I am very interested in the motion for obvious reasons.

    The recommendations of the Review Committee in the White Paper, when implemented, will have a direct bearing and significant impact on university education in Singapore. It will have major significance on how the universities will carry out their mission, as well as on how university faculty members like myself will discharge our responsibilities. I am therefore delighted to rise in support of the motion in principle and, like my fellow parliamentarians who have spoken before me, wish to see the successful transformation of these and other changes that will make JC and the diversified secondary school education truly meaningful and fulfilling for generations of students to come.

Column: 1830



    Mr Speaker, Sir, I wish to congratulate the Review Committee for its bold views, vision and ideas to transform part of the education system. In any major change effort, there is always the danger that a gap will emerge between policy intention and implementation action. Hence, it is necessary, indeed vital, for pro-active consultation, feedback and revisions to occur at the conceptual and planning stages, and not wait until implementation time before improvements will be made. Fortunately, we have heard many thoughtful and useful comments and ideas in this House on what can and should be done to bridge or narrow the gap between system ideal and action realities. It is in this spirit and with the welcoming invitation of the Minister for Education that I offer my take on the matter.

    Much has been said in the past two days, and I will not belabour some of the same points that I had originally thought of but which have since been brought up. Some of my friends said that this should be my maiden speech. But I feel that actually I am making a page-boy speech, since I am only left with a little bit to say, so as not to repeat myself and those of my colleagues.

    Instead, I would like to touch on the bigger picture about our educational reforms. The revision to the JC curriculum and the inclusion of the three new types of secondary school structures are not all there is to the educational reforms we need for our country. They form but part of the bigger picture called the learning revolution, in which active learning and lifelong education are the key words to signal the type of education required in an innovation-driven and knowledge-based new economy.

    We have heard, and sometimes robustly explained, that MOE has actually been overhauling Singapore's education system over the years, the latest being this set of recommendations. As such, the Review Committee came up with this new JC curriculum, the additional types of secondary education structures so as to offer more choices for students to receive an appropriate education at a pace suited to

Column: 1831

their learning abilities and aptitudes. Clearly, this is in response to past criticisms about our rigid educational structure and system. Nor in my mind would this be the last of the series of major changes to our education system. Given this background, Sir, I think it is important that the public should understand where the changes to the JC curriculum and secondary structures are coming from. Unfortunately - this is not the fault of the Review Committee - the White Paper did not provide this larger backdrop of how the proposed changes will fit into the overall education system for Singapore. That is why we have a lot of ideas that sometimes touch on areas which are not fair for the Committee to have commented on. I do not think that was in their terms of reference.

    We need to explain to the public, and even to Members of this House, since we all may not have been keeping up with all the changes. Whenever we think about education, we tend to recall what we had gone through and use that as part of the reference point. We need to understand what should be the overall educational goals for the whole education system and in this, I even include the pre-schools and not just primary, secondary, JC or tertiary institutions. In the light of this new world economic order, we have to find out whether the desired outcomes of education that MOE has spelt out some years back do need revisiting and updating in this globalised world. I would say that, whilst we are mindful of the need to have thinking students, a learning nation, the kind of education that we are striving for should not negate those earlier concerns we have about what a true education should be. And I recall many, many years back, SM Lee mentioning that we can be a literate nation, but not necessarily an educated one. I think that also needs restating. In this regard, I have three main concerns.

    One, the education outcomes of this revamp on the curriculum and new secondary school structures. We are trying to redress some of the over-emphasis

Column: 1832

we have on rote learning so that now we can be more creative, we can be thinking more imaginatively, we would have the means to be able to be adaptable and flexible in the new workforce, and so on and so forth. However, I would like to caution that in doing so, we do not go for form over substance as a result. We have heard how in comparison with overseas graduates, our local graduates are good in following or executing orders, that is we have content knowledge. But we are not so good when it comes to the showmanship, the ability to present, the ability to bring issues up, debate them, discuss them, and so forth. But I hope we can retain the best of both because we need both work horses as well as show horses. So it is important that students should be given the opportunities in this new revamped curriculum to be show horses but not at the expense of being able to do the work. An example of some of the dangers we have of form over substance would be, as my colleague, Dr Maliki mentioned yesterday, the danger of students wanting to be spoon-fed and not being original in their answers. In fact, they just 'cut and paste' from the Internet. They plagiarised. This is becoming an increasing concern for us.

    How do we get them to be able to craft essays well and project work well? So the communication skills are important. But I think some aspects of literature and the humanities should also be grounded in our students even though they are in the Science or Mathematics stream. In this regard, having to cross disciplines would be very welcoming. But more importantly, Sir, how would different groups of stakeholders - the parents, principals, teachers, students and employers and the public at large - take to all these proposed changes? There would be differential impact among the stakeholders here for the different types of recommendations mentioned. I think MOE needs to look into what the various stakeholders would feel and understand in terms of the various recommendations. The JC curriculum change is one; having the through-train is another; and then having specialised schools. Probably, you will not find a uniform consensus on all the

Column: 1833

changes. It will differ. I think we need to look into that. For instance, can there be room for more life skill subjects to be taught, to be incorporated into the new curriculum for the JCs and the various secondary school structures? Even though they are specialised, private or through-train, can we ensure that they form part of an all-rounded education - life skills on interpersonal relationship building, effective interpersonal communication skills, problem-solving, mediation, negotiation, etc? I know that elements of these are taught in the primary and secondary schools at different stages, but we should ensure that they continue and, in fact, go on even to the universities.

    Sir, much has been said that we need to have a mindset change for us to comprehend the profound implications of such changes for the future of our children. In this regard, the changes that we see around us, the new global effect of terrorism, the need for us to go regional and to go global, require us that we also have a good understanding of our neighbours, their history, their literature, their culture. In this regard, some of these should be incorporated, especially for those who are going on to JCs and universities. Even for those who do not, if we want to create entrepreneurs, they will also need to have a good knowledge of the market conditions in the neighbouring countries and the world, and these are subjected to social, political and economic forces.

    Another thread I would like to emphasise, and I share this with many of my parliamentary colleagues, is that we should look at how, at the pre-primary level, kindergartens and child care centres have actually incorporated project work. If you look at some of the child care centres' curriculum, they are very imaginative. Can we continue to ensure that this kind of active learning will not be stifled at the primary level? In this, I share the sentiments of my colleagues that we should not just stop with the IP and JC changes. We have heard that it is easier to start at the JC level and the upper secondary rather than to revamp all the way since we have resource constraints. Nevertheless,

Column: 1834

we need to build up our cadre of expertise, we need to have the experience and we need to change mindsets from educationalists all the way down to the employers and the public. I would like to emphasise that we have started something that is needed, and it is something that we are grappling with. In some respects, we are going into the unknown as to how we can transform our education system whereby multiple intelligences would be recognised and nurtured and not just focusing on a uni-dimension concept of intelligence.

    In conclusion, Mr Speaker, Sir, the "streaming" and "stress" issues that we have, in a way, with all these changes going on, will force a rethink, hopefully in the parents' minds of the misplaced importance that they place on just academic achievements. Hopefully, we will take pains to explain to the public how a common tool now on ranking will no longer be relevant. New forms of ranking will, in fact, take place. How do you evaluate someone who comes through on a specialised school system or a private school and rank him lineally from top to bottom? Probably, you will have different categories and we will have to include efforts for project work and co-curricular activities.

    This is probably a way to force a crisis in the parents' minds. So they will say, "I need new guidance". That is where the role of MOE and the schools becomes very important now. We have to take pains to guide the parents along. We need, in fact, some steering committee, some coordination, a better network of schools with the grassroots bodies and the VWOs coming in. In fact, Mr Speaker, Sir, I dare venture that even for some of these new types of schools, a closer, more deliberate attempt to involve the community should be made by MOE and the schools so that all these very useful suggestions that we have made will not just end up as records for us to look through, but actually, where we will put our words where our mouth is and get us involved with the schools in making sure that some of those ideas that we champion could actually be realised.

Column: 1835



    At the same time, I realise that when we create a more thinking population, it is a double-edged sword. There are also other societal changes that we must be prepared to put up with because a more thinking and creative educated citizenry of the future might also mean a certain amount of critical feedback and action, and demand for more individual choice, more freedom of action.

    This is all part and parcel of fostering a climate of intelligently thinking citizens so that even though there is divergent thinking, we have convergent interests that will propel Singapore as a first-world nation and we will continue our stride, and we can take our rightful place in this new world order. As Mr Chan Soo Sen has mentioned yesterday, there are many roads to Rome. In this set of recommendations, we are allowing some students to take the road less travelled. We wish them well.

    Mr Steve Chia Kiah Hong (Non-Constituency Member): Mr Speaker, Sir, although the 30 MPs before me have touched on most of the topics concerned, it is still my duty to rise and address these changes, especially from the non-PAP perspective.

    Sir, I speak in support of this motion in principle. Although more can and should be done to make education a learning and enjoyable experience, the proposed changes are a good start and a good sign of more positive changes to come, especially and hopefully for the lower secondary and primary levels. To that, I credit the Education Ministry and the Senior Minister of State, Mr Tharman and his Committee, for taking the effort to identify the shortcomings of our education system and make the necessary changes to make learning more relevant and enjoyable.

    Singapore has built its reputation on an open economy and free trade. To that, let us work towards a third reputation, and that is "creative spontaneity". Senior

Column: 1836

Minister Lee had said that there is something in Hong Kong that causes it to have more "buzz", and that something missing in our Singapore society to give it more buzz is this element that I term "creative spontaneity".

    We need to reduce the number of rules in our society and allow our citizens and our young to generate greater spontaneity in their actions. We also need to free the minds of our young and give them lots of room to explore; to allow them to think out of the box and identify other dimensions and angles to a problem. That is creative thinking at work. Together with the spontaneous action to experiment and try, it will create greater buzz as our society develops. Our current education system churns out a production line of workers, managers and instruction takers. This used to satisfy the needs of our industries during our development years, but not anymore. We have reached a First World economy and no longer in the league of those cheap manufacturing bases. The road ahead is unclear and paved with stiff competition. Singapore businesses must compete on ideas, innovation and originality.

    The quality and standards of our future workforce to be churned out through our current education system is no longer going to be adequate. We need more thinkers, creators and innovators. We do not need more order-takers. We need them to be spontaneous and gung-ho in spirit and in action. We also need to remove the standard pathways for future generations. As what Mr Chan Soo Sen said yesterday, there is more than one road that leads to Rome. And the road less travelled may bring more meaning and fulfilment to life than the congested highways that every graduate seems to be scrambling to get on.

    It must be clear also in the minds of the students and their parents that having a degree or even a Government scholarship may not be the best career path for them anymore. If they are that good, they do not need a scholarship to chart a future for them. To be very successful, they may even need to follow the footsteps of Bill

Column: 1837

Gates - leave school and follow their dreams. The nature of careers has evolved so radically and dramatically that there is no longer one standard career pathway. For example, a person can be very highly paid just by playing and testing computer games.

    Let it also be clear in our young children's minds and their parents' that they do not need a degree or scholarship to be successful in society and in life. What they need is this ability to free their minds from the standard pathways set by the Government and society, and take the gung-ho spirit of "can-do, just-do-it and never-say-die" spirit. It is no longer what degrees or scholarships you have that are important, but what innovative ideas and patents you own that make your future. We need to be creative and to be spontaneous at that too.

    When the proposed Junior College and Upper Secondary education review is fully implemented across all schools, I hope this new cohort will be the generation that will bring about more buzz and vibrancy into our Singaporean society.

    Sir, as I first mentioned in the debate on the Budget Statement in May, there is a great need to develop "thinking creativity" in our young. We need to inculcate the inquisitive spirit in them. They need to learn to ask tough questions like "why" and "why not", and develop the courage and tenacity to explore and give it many tries. By asking "why", they learn to explore the fundamental concerns surrounding that issue, and develop their own justification that they will internalise into their being. So, questions asked by Senior Minister of State Dr Vivian Balakrishnan's son like, "Why must I die for Singapore?" is highly relevant and important to the psychological and character development of the child.

    To survive and prosper in this knowledge economy, we need to free our minds. The revised JC emphasis on thinking and communication skills is a good start, but it is not enough. Like what Dr Jennifer Lee mentioned the day before, the Education Ministry needs to bring it all

Column: 1838

the way down to pre-primary and primary level. The children in the schools need to be encouraged to ask questions, and tough questions too. The teachers need not have all the answers to these tough questions like "why" or "why not". But at the very least, the teachers should encourage these questions, and force the students to go home and think about it for the next few days, and ask their parents or their friends. We will be surprised by the range of replies that could be thrown up by the children in their search for answers. Participation and answers with wit or originality should be given greater assessment credits.

    Such processes will also build up the communicative skills in our young children to communicate their thinking and ideas to the class and authorities in a benign setting. This will be the key to their future success, and has to be done starting from primary level. It will be too late to turn the engine of thinking on only when they reach the JC level.

    Sir, as I see it now, if there is one skill that international talents have in abundance over Singaporeans, it is their ability to talk their way out and argue convincingly. Column: 1839

When that is successfully done, there will be more hope for our future.

    In order to facilitate greater interactions between students and teachers, the class size needs to be cut. A big class is useful for the one-way impartation of knowledge.     Our children and future leaders must be equipped with the right thinking skills to reinvent themselves and acquire specific work skills to stay relevant. There is no job security these days.     Mr Speaker, Sir, I will now touch on the second part of the motion - having greater diversity and the opening of new pathways to cater to the different strengths of students. for the average sons of the rich, famous or connected. I hope the Ministry will put sufficient checks in place to ensure that only the top per cent in each cohort will be admitted - based on intelligence and academic ability, and not on family backgrounds, links or contributions.

kindness, gentleness, compassion, integrity and respect for others are not internalised into the character building process.
